results.title: Oxygen: an introduction to chemistry
results.creator_credit: Jim Callner, Hans Halberstadt and Barr Films
results.brief_description: Explores the nature of oxygen. Shows that oxygen has three forms: solid, liquid and gas, and that when it combines with other atoms it forms new chemical compounds. Illustrates how animals use oxygen to release energy for activity and how plants use carbon dioxide to produce oxygen.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jim Callner, Hans Halberstadt and Barr Films

results.title: Human and animal beginnings. - 2nd ed.
results.brief_description: Uses the reproduction of small animals to introduce children to human reproduction. Emphasises the role of families in caring for the newborn. Suitable for primary level.

results.title: How we know the earth moves. - Rev. ed.
results.brief_description: Shows how scientists came to understand that the Earth spins on its axis and that it travels around the Sun. Discusses the contributions made by Copernicus and Foucault, as well as early observations of the movements of constellations. Explains the Foucault pendulum and involves students in a demonstration illustrating star shift. Suitable for lower and middle secondary levels.

results.title: Color in nature
results.creator_credit: Konstantin Grigoriev and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Explores the function of coloration in both plants and animals using nature footage and close-up photography. Examines how color can benefit living organisms in their environment; shows how pigments can cause different colors; identifies the pigment chlorophyll as an essential element in the process of photosynthesis. Suitable for upper primary and secondary levels.

results.title: Animals of the Arctic
results.creator_credit: Karl Maslowski, Stephen Maslowski and Centron Films
results.brief_description: This film introduces students to the wide variety of wildlife that roams the plains and seashores of the Arctic. It shows how the animals and birds have adapted to their environment. Photography: Karl and Stephen Maslowski. Suitable for upper primary, lower and middle secondary levels.

results.title: Great clean-up
results.creator_credit: James Carney, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Examines the environmental problems of the Great lakes area and reports on the steps that have been taken in an attempt to correct these problems.

results.title: Ghanaian Village
results.brief_description: Looks at a day in the life of a family living in a Ghanaian fishing village. Division of labour, preparation of food and daily activity are some of the highlights.

results.title: Fish: the food with a catch to it
results.brief_description: Overview of the scope of the fishing industry: identifies the world’s leading fishing nations and illustrates the immense variety of fish caught. Traditional and modern methods of locating, catching, processing and preserving seafoods are shown. Also investigates the expanding activity in aquaculture or “fish farming”.

results.title: Thingumajigs = Trouvailles ou bizarreries
results.creator_credit: Raymond Garceau, Paul Larose and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This is a film about creations, and the inventors who ride them, drive them, row them, and look at them. Unpredictable, the creations sometimes develop minds of their own. Sound film without words.

results.title: Hansel & Gretel (An Appalachian Version)
results.brief_description: A version of the tale of the Grimm brothers filmed in the Blue Ridge Mountains of Virginia. Stars Scott Honeycutt, Aeron Mack, Marlene Elbin and Philip Eastham.
